	File.list().length =3D=3D 14

How does this work for something that isn't =
a primitive type like int, 
boolean, or even String?

If I got you right, y=
ou throw a lot of inputs at the methods to be tested, 
and try to come up w=
ith boundary values. 
Why do I need this? 
Consider some multiply(int, int)=
 method.
Every programmer knows that numeric variables can overflow, so I w=
ould 
neither document that nor expect the code to somehow having a guard 
=
against this. This is IMHO the job of the VM (throwing something like an 
A=
rithmeticException).

> Combined with Agitator's ability to automatically g=
enerate very 
> relevant test data and achieve very high code coverage auto=
matically 

How is it "automatic" if I have to check the test data / assert=
ions 
manually?
If the test data is always boundary conditions (e.g. always=
 pass null 
instead of a real object) this will break my code in many place=
s, but I 
do not want to check for null each time. Passing null is a progra=
mming 
error made by whatever code calls my code. If the tool still bogs me=
 
about every method because my code crashed when null was used, the tool 
=
becomes useless. Like those warning labels "Floor may be slippery when 
wet=
"... yeah, I know that.
